clinical_study.official_title: Venopuncture-Free IVF: Can "Patient-friendly" Salivary Hormone Measurements Replace Serum Monitoring of IVF Patients?

brief_summary.textblock: This study aims to determine the performance of a salivary hormone competitive immunoassay for monitoring patients during treatment for infertility.

detailed_description.textblock: The goal of this study is to determine the performance of a salivary hormone competitive immunoassay for monitoring patient estrogen and progesterone levels during treatment for infertility using controlled ovarian stimulation (COH) and in vitro fertilization (IVF). Specifically, inter- and intra-assay precision, correlation with serum measurements (the gold-standard), and user satisfaction will be determined. Ultimately, the potential applicability and reliability of salivary steroid monitoring in IVF cycles will be assessed.

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case-Only, Time Perspective: Prospective

primary_outcome.measure: Equivalence of Salivary Steroid Monitoring to Blood Based Monitoring
primary_outcome.description: The potential applicability and reliability of salivary steroid monitoring during infertility treatment will be measured as a progression during a patient's IVF stimulation cycle. Concurrent saliva and blood draw measurements of Estradiol and Progesterone will be taken between 3-5 times during a 2-week monitoring period. Equivalence will be determined by the matched progression of Estradiol and progesterone levels (pg/ml) in the same patient at the concurrent times. Saliva Estradiol and Progesterone levels are of a magnitude of 100-200 less than serum based values and are converted using an algorithm to adjust to serum equivalence. Matched T-test will be used to test the hypothesis that the two methods are not statistically different.

secondary_outcome.description: Qualitative data from subjects via a questionnaire assessing tolerability and anxiety of sample collection comparing saliva versus venopuncture.

arm_group.description: Patients undergoing ovulation induction and controlled ovarian hyperstimulation at Boston IVF
